skill.description: Use when writing or reviewing TypeScript code. Enforces strict mode standards, explicit typing, and best practices. Prevents 'any' types, @ts-ignore comments, and non-null assertions. This is a COMPREHENSIVE skill - consult the detailed guides before writing any TypeScript code.

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation and static analysis skill with minimal risk. The validation script reads TypeScript files for pattern matching using regex. No network calls, no credential access, no code execution beyond local file reading. Safe for publishing.

content.value_statement: Writing TypeScript without strict mode leads to runtime errors and maintainability issues. This skill provides comprehensive patterns for explicit typing, type guards, and error handling so AI assistants generate production-ready TypeScript code from the first line.
actual_capabilities: Generate TypeScript with explicit types and no implicit any
Create type guards for runtime validation of external data
Implement error handling patterns like Result and Either types
Type React components, hooks, and event handlers correctly
Validate TypeScript files for strict mode violations
Apply utility types, generics, and mapped types appropriately
limitations: Does not execute TypeScript code or run type checking
Does not modify files or commit code automatically
Does not install dependencies or configure build tools
Requires user to run validation script manually before committing

output: interface User { id: string; name: string; email: string }

best_practices: Always use type guards to validate external data before type assertions
Never use any type - prefer unknown with narrowing or explicit interfaces
Include explicit return types on all functions for better type inference
Write tests for all type guards and validation functions
anti_patterns: Using any type instead of explicit types or unknown
Using @ts-ignore to silence errors instead of fixing the underlying issue
Using non-null assertion (!) instead of optional chaining or type guards
Leaving implicit any in function parameters or missing return types

faq.question: Which TypeScript versions are supported?
faq.answer: Supports TypeScript 4.9+ including satisfies operator and template literal types.

faq.question: Does this skill replace TypeScript compiler?
faq.answer: No - this provides patterns for correct code. Run tsc for actual type checking.

faq.question: How do I integrate with my project?
faq.answer: Add the skill reference and run validate-types.py before committing to catch violations.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes - validation only reads files and uses regex. No data leaves your machine.

faq.question: Why avoid the any type?
faq.answer: Any bypasses type checking entirely. Use unknown with guards or explicit interfaces for safety.

faq.question: How does this differ from ESLint?
faq.answer: ESLint catches style issues. This skill teaches correct patterns for every TypeScript scenario.
